The Latin hexameter uses this caesura more frequently than

(1) that it is strong and distinct 3 (2) that it allows the use of either a dactyl or a spondee in the third foot3 (3) that it al- ways produces conflict in the third foot3 (4) that, with this caesura, conflict in the second, and especially in the fourth foot is more easily obtained. In the example quoted (Ι), conflict occurs only in the third foot and is produced by the caesura. The comparative frequency of such verses in the satires of Horace and Juvenal is a mark of the freedom of the department.
